title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part A
abstract: Illumination enhances the protein abundance of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca 2+-ATPases-like transporter in the ctenidium and whitish inner mantle of the giant clam, Tridacna squamosa, to augment exogenous Ca 2+ uptake and shell formation, respectively

abstract.text: Illumination enhances the protein abundance of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca 2+-ATPases-like transporter in the ctenidium and whitish inner mantle of the giant clam, Tridacna squamosa, to augment exogenous Ca 2+ uptake and shell formation, respectively

body_text.text: Giant clams of genus Tridacna or Hippopus reside in coral reefs of the tropical Indo-Pacific (Rosewater, 1965) . They harbour symbiotic dinoflagellates (Family: Symbiodiniaceae) of genera Symbiodinium, Cladocopium and Durusdinium (Takabayashi et al., 2004; Hernawan, 2008; LaJeunesse et al., 2018) . The symbiotic dinoflagellates live extracellularly as non-motile coccoid symbionts, also known as zooxanthellae, in the lumen of a branched tubular system inside the host. They reside abundantly in tiny tertiary tubules in the fleshy, extensible and colourful mantle that contains host pigments and iridocytes .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In addition, substantial quantities of symbionts are located in a special region of the whitish inner mantle, near the hinge of the shell valves (Poo et al., 2020) . The inner mantle is in touch with the extrapallial fluid and partakes in shell formation. During insolation, symbionts in the outer mantle, but not those in the inner mantle, can upregulate the protein abundance of form II Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/ oxygenase for photosynthesis (Poo et al., 2020) . The photosynthates produced can be shared with the host and support 100% of the hosts' nutritional requirements (Fitt et al., 1986) . This allows giant clams to grow more rapidly and perform light-enhanced shell formation (Sano et al., 2012; Ip et al., 2017; Rossbach et al., 2019) , in spite of the scarcity of organic nutrients in tropical waters (Lucas et al., 1989) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Shell formation (calcification) involves the deposition of calcium carbonate (Ca 2+ + HCO 3 − ⇔ CaCO 3 + H + ) from the extrapallial fluid onto the inner surface of the shell-valve. As H + is generated during calcification, the removal of the released H + can enhance the rate of shell formation. Indeed, exposure of the fluted giant clam, Tridacna squamosa, to light leads to a significant increase in the pH of the extrapallial fluid which is in immediate contact with the inside surface of the half shell (Ip et al., 2006) . H + could combine with NH 3 in the extrapallial fluid to form NH 4 + , which is transported into the shell-facing epithelial cells of the inner mantle through some unknown transporters (Ip et al., 2006) , or it could be transferred into the epithelial cells through Plasma Membrane Ca 2+ -ATPase (PMCA; Ip et al., 2018) . Subsequently, the excess H + can be translocated to the hemolymph and excreted through the apical beta Na + /H + Exchanger 3 (βNHE-like) located in the seawater-facing epithelium of the inner mantle (Cao-Pham et al., 2019) . Some of the excess H + can also be shuttled through the hemolymph to the ctenidium for excretion by a homolog of Na + /H + Exchanger 3 (NHE3-like; Hiong et al., 2017) or Vacuolar-type H + -ATPase (VHA; Ip et al., 2018) . It has been established that the expression levels of these three H + transport mechanisms can be enhanced in T. squamosa during illumination (Cao-Pham et al., 2019; Hiong et al., 2017; Ip et al., 2018) . Accordingly, light-enhanced shell formation demands greater secretion of Ca 2+ from the shell-facing epithelial cells of the inner mantle into the extrapallial fluid. Indeed, two Ca 2+ transporters, PMCA (Ip et al., 2017) and a homolog of Na + /Ca 2+ exchanger 3 (NCX3-like; Boo et al., 2019) , have been identified for such a function. They are located in the apical membrane of the shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle, and their gene and protein expression levels increase significantly in the inner mantle of T. squamosa during light exposure (Ip et al., 2017; Boo et al., 2019) . As follows, there must be increases in the uptake of Ca 2+ by the shell-facing epithelial cells of the inner mantle from the hemolymph. However, how the absorbed Ca 2+ traverse these cells, from the basolateral membrane to the apical membrane and made available to the apical PMCA and NCX3-like, without perturbing the cytosolic Ca 2+ concentration is enigmatic at present.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Ultimately, the Ca 2+ needed for shell formation must be derived from the ambient seawater. Like other aquatic mollusks, giant clams possess a pair of ctenidium (gill) positioned inside the mantle cavity. A ctenidium is a multi-functional organ that is key in respiration. It is comb-like in shape and comprises many filaments and numerous tertiary water channels, which increases the surface area for gas exchange (Norton and Jones, 1992) . In some mollusks, the ctenidium also functions in ionoregulation and acid-base balance (Hu et al., 2014) . Recently, Cao-Pham et al. (2019b) have obtained the complete coding cDNA sequence of a homolog of Voltage-gated Calcium Channel subunit α1 (CACNA1-like) from the ctenidium of T. squamosa and characterized it as the α1D subunit of L-type voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC). It is apically localized in the epithelial cells of filaments and tertiary water channels in the ctenidium, suggesting that it is well-placed to uptake exogenous Ca 2+ . As the protein abundance of CACNA1-like increases significantly in the ctenidium of individuals exposed to light for 12 h, ctenidial VGCC could play a role in augmenting exogenous Ca 2+ uptake in support of lightenhanced shell formation during insolation. But then, how the absorbed Ca 2+ traverse ctenidial epithelial cells from the apical membrane associated with seawater to the basolateral membrane associated with the hemolymph has not been elucidated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Notably, the concentration of Ca 2+ is highly regulated inside cellular compartments of mammals, such as humans and mice (Stewart and Davis, 2019) , and marine invertebrates, such as nemerteans and mollusks (Deguchi et al., 2015) , because Ca 2+ partakes in the delicate regulation of many cell signaling pathways. The resting free Ca 2+ concentration in the cytosol is maintained at ~100 nM, which is much lower than the free Ca 2+ concentration of ~1.2 mM in the extracellular fluid (Carafoli, 2002) . Inside the cell, Ca 2+ concentration gradients exist between the cytosol and the lumens of some organelles, such as sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) or endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi apparatus (Berridge et al., 2003) . These organelles serve as Ca 2+ stores, facilitated by luminal Ca 2+ -binding proteins, such as calsequestrin and calreticulin (Berridge et al., 2003) . Ca 2+ homeostasis involves three families of P2-type ATPases: the plasma membrane sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca 2+ -ATPases (SERCAs), secretory-pathway Ca 2+ -ATPases (SPCAs), and plasma membrane Ca 2+ -ATPases (PMCAs) (Carafoli, 2002; Blaustein and Lederer, 1999) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Among the three families of Ca 2+ -transport ATPases, only SERCAs are characterized by two Ca 2+ -transport sites, designated site I and site II, with high affinity to Ca 2+ . Consequently, per one ATP hydrolyzed, SERCAs can transport two Ca 2+ ions, but the PMCAs and SPCAs bind to and transport only one Ca 2+ ion (where the binding site corresponds to site II of SERCA). Both SPCAs and SERCAs are responsible for filling the non-mitochondrial intracellular stores with Ca 2+ (Wuytack et al., 2002) . Specifically, SPCA1 is an intracellular Ca 2+ pump found mostly in the Golgi apparatus, and it functions to sequester Ca 2+ into this organelle (Van Baelen et al., 2003) . In comparison, SERCAs are active Ca 2+ transporters present in the SR, and they function to maintain the low concentration of cytosolic Ca 2+ . In humans, multiple SERCA isoforms (SERCAla, b, SERCA2a-c, and SERCA3a-f) are generated from three genes (ATP2A1, ATP2A2 and ATP2A3) through developmental or tissuespecific alternative splicing (Hovnanian, 2007) . Vertebrates typically show three SERCA genes due to two successive genome duplications (Wuytack et al., 2002; Altshuler et al., 2012) . In vertebrates, SERCA1a is present predominantly in adult fast-twitch muscles, whereas SERCA1b is expressed during neonatal development. SERCA2a is expressed mainly in cardiac and slow-twitch skeletal muscles. SERCA2b is expressed ubiquitously in all tissue types, but SERCA2c is expressed only in cardiac muscles. SERCA3 is expressed in various non-muscle tissues (Periasamy and Kalyanasundaram, 2007) . By contrast, most invertebrates, including the starlet sea anemone, Nematostella vectensis (Putnam et al., 2007) , and the placozoan, Trichoplax adhaerens (Srivastava et al., 2008) , contain only one SERCA gene in their genome. According to Wuytack et al. (2002) , the single SERCA gene of invertebrates could be a homolog of the vertebrate SERCA2 gene (ATP2A2).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Intracellular Ca 2+ participates in muscle contraction by interacting with regulatory proteins, like troponin C, associated with actin filaments. This shifts the positions of the troponin complexes on thin filaments, exposing myosin-binding sites on the actin molecules so that they can interact with the thick filament to generate the power stroke for contraction (Wakabayashi, 2015) . Ca 2+ needed for this process is stored predominantly in the SR, and SERCA is the primary transporter sequestering cytosolic Ca 2+ into the SR for storage during muscle relaxation (Bers, 1997) . Under certain conditions, the electrochemical potential gradient of Ca 2+ between the SR and the cytosol could drive ATP synthesis through SERCA during the exit of Ca 2+ from SR into the cytosol (Meis, 2000) . In mammary glands of lactating mammals, SERCA2 participates in milk production, serving a minor role in Ca 2+ enrichment of milk (Faddy et al., 2008) . It is involved in Ca 2+ transport inside the secretory cells of the mammary gland, regulating intracellular Ca 2+ homeostasis and reducing the risk of hypocalcaemia (Laporta et al., 2013) . SERCA can also participate in mineralisation of the exoskeleton during ecdysis in arthropods. In the wood louse, Porcellio scaber, the anterior sternal epithelial cells function to transport cuticular Ca 2+ to and from sternal CaCO 3 deposits. The mRNA abundance of SERCA increases in these cells from early premoult to late premoult, or from early premoult to intramoult, indicating its role in transcellular Ca 2+ movement (Hagedorn et al., 2003) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As information on transcellular Ca 2+ transport in giant clams is unavailable, this study was undertaken to elucidate the role of SERCA in intracellular Ca 2+ transport through cells of the ctenidial epithelium as well as cells of the seawater facing epithelium of the inner mantle in T. squamosa. We cloned the complete cDNA sequence of a homolog of SERCA (SERCA-like) from the ctenidium and the inner mantle of T. squamosa. A custom-made anti-SERCA-like antibody was made to elucidate the subcellular localization of SERCA-like in the ctenidium and the inner mantle using immunofluorescence microscopy. Efforts were made to determine the effects of light exposure on transcript levels and protein abundance of SERCA-like/SERCA-like in the ctenidium and the inner mantle. The hypothesis tested was that light exposure would lead to changes in the gene and/or protein expression levels of SERCA-like/ SERCA-like in the ctenidium and the inner mantle to support lightenhanced Ca 2+ absorption and light-enhanced shell formation, respectively.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Tridacna squamosa specimens (520 ± 180 g; N = 20) were acquired from Xanh Tuoi Tropical Fish, Ltd. (Vietnam) and housed under a 12 h light:12 h dark regime for a duration of one month inside three glass tanks (length 90 cm x width 62 cm x height 60 cm) before exposure to various experimental conditions. Each tank contained 350 L of recirculating seawater with water conditions as follow: salinity, 30-32; temperature, ~25 • C; pH, 8.1-8.3; hardness, 143-179 ppm; calcium, 380-420 ppm; phosphate, <0.25 ppm; nitrate, 0 ppm; nitrite, 0 ppm; total ammonia, <0.25 ppm. The tank was illuminated with two sets of Aquazonic T5 lighting systems (400-700 nm; Yi Hu Fish Farm Trading, Singapore), each with four 39 W fluorescence tubes (90 cm; 2× Sun tubes and 2× Actinic blue tubes), from the top. The shaded light intensity measured at the depth of the giant clams under water using a Light Meter Lux/FC, model no 840020 (SPER Scientific Inc., USA) was 120 PPFD (μmol m − 2 s − 1 ). At the end of the different time points for each experimental condition, clams were anesthetized in 0.2% phenoxyethanol and forced open to cut the adductor muscles. The left and right ctenidia and inner mantle were excised, blotted dry and freeze-clamped with aluminium tongs cooled in liquid nitrogen. Samples were stored at − 80 • C. Four individuals subjected to darkness for 12 h were sacrificed (N = 4), while another 12 clams were exposed to light for 3, 6 or 12 h (N = 4 each light condition) and subsequently sacrificed for tissue sampling to study the effects of illumination on the expression levels of SERCAlike/SERCA-like of T. squamosa. As giant clams would never be exposed to more than 12 h of darkness in nature, it would not be appropriate to incorporate parallel control into our experimental design. Hence, individuals exposed to 12 h of darkness were arbitrarily regarded as the control to facilitate the performance of statistical analysis. Nonetheless, it is important to take note that the different time points of the experiments including 12 h of darkness represented different phase of their natural light cycle. For immunofluorescence microscopy, the ctenidia and inner mantle tissue samples were collected from individuals which had been exposed to either darkness or light for 12 h, respectively (N = 2 for each condition).
body_text.section: Animal, experimental conditions, sampling

body_text.text: Total RNA was extracted from the ctenidium and inner mantle using TRI Reagent™ (Sigma-Aldrich Co. St. Louis, MO, USA) and purified using PureLink RNA Mini Kit (Invitrogen). Quantification of purified total RNA was then done using a Shimadzu BioSpec-nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Corporation, Tokyo, Japan). The integrity of the total RNA was verified through electrophoresis. cDNA synthesis was conducted by reverse transcribing purified total RNA into cDNA using the RevertAid™ first-strand cDNA synthesis kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Carlsbad, CA, USA).
body_text.section: Total RNA extraction and cDNA synthesis

body_text.text: The PCR primers used to isolate the partial SERCA-like sequence from the ctenidium and the inner mantle of T. squamosa (Forward: 5 ′ -GGGCTATCAACATTGGACAT-3 ′ ; Reverse: 5 ′ -TCATGGATTTCCTGT-CACGG-3 ′ ) were constructed from the homologous regions of Hyriopsis cumingii SERCA (KP313822.1), Crassostrea virginica SERCA (XM_022487478.1), and Placopecten magellanicus SERCA (AF022228.1). PCR was done in a 9902 Veriti 96-well thermal cycle (Thermo Fisher Scientific) using DreamTaq™ polymerase (Thermo Fisher Scientific). PCR was performed with initial denaturation for 3 min at 95 • C, accompanied by 40 cycles of denaturation, annealing and extension at 95 • C for 30 s, 55 • C for 30 s and 72 • C for 30 s, respectively, and a final extension at 72 • C for 10 min. PCR products were separated using agarose gel electrophoresis. Then, bands of the estimated size were extracted from the gels using Wizard® SV Gel and PCR Clean-Up System (Promega, Madison, WI, USA). Sequencing was performed using Big-Dye® Terminator v3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and then purified by ethanol/sodium acetate precipitation, before being processed using the 3130XL Genetic Analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The PCR amplicons were cloned using pGEM®-T Easy vector (Promega), in accordance to the methods of Hiong et al. (2017a) . Multiple clones were sequenced to obtain partial SERCA-like fragments. No isoforms were found. Subsequently, RACE-PCR was done using the SMARTer RACE cDNA amplification kit (Clontech Laboratories, Mountain View, CA) and a pair of RACE-PCR primers (5 ′ RACE: 5 ′ -GACAGA CAAGACTGGACTGAACAAGAG-3 ′ ; 3'RACE: 5 ′ -AGACCTTCTGGGA-TAGCAGCTACA-3 ′ ) to attain the full coding sequence of SERCA-like.
body_text.section: PCR, rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE)-PCR, cloning and sequencing

body_text.text: The SERCA-like amino acid sequence was translated using ExPASy Proteomic server (https://web.expasy.org/translate/). To confirm the identity of SERCA-like, a phenogramic analysis was performed with other SERCA sequences obtained from Genbank ( Supplementary Table  S1 ). Maximum-likelihood analysis using RaxML v8.2.5 (Stamatakis, 2014) with 1000 bootstrap replicates was performed. Via ModelGenerator v0.85 (Keane et al., 2006) , the best-fit model under Akaike Information Criterion was determined to be LG (Whelan and Goldman, 2001 ). The transmembrane regions (TMs) were predicted using the TOPCONS protein structure prediction server (Tsirigos et al., 2015;  http://topcons.cbr.su.se/).
body_text.section: Amino acid sequence and phylogenetic analysis

body_text.text: cDNA of both inner mantle (2 μg) and ctenidium (4 μg) were synthesized from RNA using random hexamer primers and RevertAid™ first strand cDNA synthesis kit. The absolute quantification of SERCA-like transcripts was determined through qPCR, performed using a StepOne-Plus™ Real-Time PCR System (Thermo Fisher Scientific), with a pair of qPCR primers (forward: 5 ′ -GAAGAAACCACCTCGTAGTCC-3 ′ ; reverse: 5 ′ -GCAGCACCAACAGTAGCA-3 ′ ) and following the methods of Hiong et al. (2017a) , albeit with slight modifications. The qPCR reactions contained a 10 μl reaction volume consisting of 5 μl of 2× qPCRBIO SyGreen Mix Hi-ROX (PCR Biosystems), 0.2 μmol l − 1 each of specific forward and reverse primers and 1 ng of sample cDNA. The cycling conditions were as follows: initial 20 s of denaturation and enzyme activation at 95 • C, 40 cycles of 95 • C for 3 s and 62 • C for 30 s. The overall amplification efficiency for the SERCA-like primers is 98.4%. The transcript level of SERCA-like was determined utilizing a plasmid standard curve of serially diluted plasmids, constructed according to methods of Hiong et al. (2017a) .
body_text.section: Qualitative real-time PCR (qPCR)

body_text.text: A rabbit polyclonal anti-SERCA-like antibody was custom-made by GenScript against residues 20-33 (EEAGLTDDQVKRSR) of SERCA-like of T. squamosa. The anti-α-tubulin antibody (12G10) was procured from the Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank produced under the auspices of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development and preserved by the University of Iowa.
body_text.section: Antibodies

body_text.text: Protein extraction from the ctenidium and inner mantle tissues were carried out in accordance with the procedures of Hiong et al. (2017a) , with some modifications. Protein samples (20 μg) from the ctenidium and inner mantle were separated in an 8% acrylamide gel containing SDS. Subsequently, the gel would be trans-blotted onto a nitrocellulose membrane. Western blotting was then performed using Pierce Fast Western Blot kit, SuperSignal® West Pico Substrate (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The membranes were incubated with either anti-SERCA-like antibodies at 1:8000 (1.25 μg ml − 1 ) or anti-α-tubulin antibodies at 1:15000 (0.67 μg ml − 1 ) for 1 h at 25 • C, before incubation with optimized anti-rabbit or anti-mouse secondary antibodies respectively, at 25 • C for 15 min. The membranes were washed six times using Fast Western Wash Buffer, before visualization by chemiluminescence provided in the Fast Western Blot kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and using ChemiDoc™ Imaging Systems (Bio-Rad Laboratories). The optical density of SERCA-like band was quantified using ImageJ (version 1.52a, NIH), calibrated with a 21-step reflection scanner scale (1 ′′ 9 8 ′′ ; Stouffer #R3705-IC) and then normalized using α-tubulin.
body_text.section: Sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and western blotting

body_text.text: Inner mantle and ctenidia samples were processed according to the method of Hiong et al. (2017a) . Antigen retrieval was conducted by incubating the sections in citraconic anhydride (pH 7.4) (Nacalai Tesque) at 95 • C for 5 min, followed with incubation for 10 min in 1% SDS in TPBS (0.05% Tween 20 in Phosphate-buffered saline: 10 mmol l − 1 Na 2 HPO 4 , 1.8 mmol l − 1 KH 2 PO 4 , 137 mmol l − 1 NaCl, 2.7 mmol l − 1 KCl, pH 7.4) at room temperature. Sections were blocked using 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in TPBS (blocking buffer) for 1 h at room temperature to minimize non-specific binding. Subsequently, sections were incubated overnight with anti-SERCA-like antibody at a dilution of 1:600 (1.67 μg ml − 1 in blocking buffer) in TPBS, followed with incubation with goat anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor-488 (1:800 dilution; 2.5 μg ml − 1 ; Invitrogen) in TPBS for 1 h at 37 • C. The sections were then rinsed three times using TPBS, before staining with 4 ′ 6'-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Sigma-Aldrich Co.) nuclear stain. Sections were mounted in Prolong Gold Antifade Mountant (Life Technologies Corporation). With an Olympus BX-60 epifluorescence microscope (Olympus Corporation, Tokyo, Japan), images were captured at 50-100 ms exposure, using Cell Sens digital imaging software (Olympus Corporation) and an Olympus DP73 digital camera (Olympus Corporation). The green fluorescence of Alexa Fluor-488 was examined using the Olympus U-WNIBA Blue Fluorescence Filter (excitation wavelengths: 470-490 nm; emission wavelengths: 515-550 nm). Differential interference contract (DIC) images of tissue morphology were obtained using an Olympus U-DICT DIC slider. All images were overlaid using Adobe Photoshop CC (Adobe Systems, USA).
body_text.section: Immunofluorescence microscopy

body_text.text: Statistical analysis was done via IBM SPSS Statistics version 20 software (IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY, USA). The results in Fig. 5 and 6 were presented as means + S.E.M. The homogeneity of variance was analyzed using Levene's test, followed by using One-Way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) to evaluate differences among means. Means with equal variance and unequal variance were analyzed with Tukey's posthoc test and Dunnett's T3 post-hoc test, respectively. Differences were deemed statistically significant when (P < 0.05).
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: The full cDNA coding sequences of SERCA-like obtained from the ctenidium and inner mantle of T. squamosa were identical and had been deposited into Genbank with the accession number, KT962828. It comprised 3009 bp that encoded a protein with 1002 amino acids of 110.6 kDa. The deduced SERCA-like amino acid contained 10 predicted TMs (Fig. 1) . It also contained a phosphorylation site of SERCA, DKTGTLT, and a putative SR/ER retention signal domain, KILLL (Fig. 1) . Additionally, it consisted of two Ca 2+ -binding sites (I and II) in the TMs, a FITC-binding site as well as a FITC-reaction site (Fig. 1) . A phenogramic analysis showed that the SERCA-like was grouped with other SERCAs from bivalves (Fig. 2) . The similarity between the amino acid sequence of SERCA-like of T. squamosa and those of SERCA2a, SERCA1, SERCA2b and SERCA3 of Homo sapiens were 73.16%, 73.11%, 70.66%, and 65.39%, respectively. Due to its high equivalent similarities with SERCA2a and SERCA1, it was not possible to confirm the exact identify of SERCA-like of T. squamosa, although it had been proposed that the single SERCA gene of invertebrates could be a homolog of the vertebrate SERCA2 gene (Wuytack et al., 2002) . There were also high similarities between SERCA-like of T. squamosa and the three SERCA isoforms of Pinctada fucata (86.03% for PSERC, 85.23% for PSERA and 83.98% for PSERB).
body_text.section: Nucleotide sequences, amino acid sequences and phenogramic analysis

body_text.text: Due to the low resolution of fluorescence microscopy, fluorescence of ER would manifest as fluorescence of the cytoplasm. Indeed, SERCA-like was immunolocalised non-uniformly in the cytoplasm, presumable in the ER membranes, of the epithelial cells in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. SERCA-like-immunofluorescence was apparently stronger in the cytoplasm adjacent to the apical membrane of the ctenidial filaments in individuals exposed to 12 h of light (Fig. 3B, C) than that in the controls kept in darkness for 12 h (Fig. 3E, F) . Reproducible results were obtained from to experimental and two control individuals. In the inner mantle of T. squamosa, SERCA-like immunolabeling was detected in the epithelial cells of the shell-facing epithelium, but not those of the seawater-facing epithelium. In the shell-facing epithelial cells, SERCAlike was also immunolocalized in the cytoplasm non-uniformly, with more intense staining near the apical region of the cells in individuals exposed to 12 h of light (Fig. 4B, C) than that in the controls kept in darkness for 12 h (Fig. 4E, F) . Reproducible results were obtained from two experimental and two control individuals. The validity of SERCAlike immunolabeling was confirmed by peptide competition assays ( Supplementary Fig. S1, Supplementary Fig. S2 ).

However, in the inner mantle, the transcript level of SERCA-like remained unchanged throughout all conditions with reference to control (Fig. 5B) .

The protein abundance of SERCA-like in both the ctenidium (Fig. 6A ) and inner mantle (Fig. 6B ) increased significantly after 6 h or 12 h of light exposure with reference to the control (P < 0.05).

body_text.text: SERCA-like of T. squamosa contains 10 predicted TMs (Fig. 1) . It consists of the highly conserved phosphorylation site of SERCA, DKTGTLT (Asp 363 -Thr 369 ), with the critical residue Asp involved in phosphorylation by protein kinase C (Fig. 1) . In addition, a putative SR/ ER retention signal, KILLL (Lys 69 -Leu 73 ), is conserved across SERCAs of invertebrates including T. squamosa, P. scaber and P. clarkii (Fig. 1) . In SERCAs of Drosophila melanogaster and mammals, KILLL serves as a signal recognition domain for their integration into the membrane of organelles (Magyar and Váradi, 1990) . Thus, the KILLL motif may serve a similar function in SERCA-like of T. squamosa. Furthermore, two Ca 2+ -binding sites, I and II, can be found in SERCAlike of T. squamosa; Ca 2+ -binding site I comprises Asn 797 and Leu 800 of TM5, Thr 828 of TM6, and Phe 952 of TM8, while Ca 2+ -binding site II consists of Val 316 , Ala 317 , Ile 319 and Glu 321 of TM4, and Asn 852 of TM6. Mutagenesis studies of Ca 2+ binding sites in SERCAs showed that mutation of critical residues Glu 309 , Asn 796 and Thr 799 would result in the loss of Ca 2+ transport and Ca 2+ -dependent phosphoenzyme formation (Clarke et al., 1989) . Mutation of glutamate at position 309, which corresponds to Glu 321 in SERCA-like of T. squamosa in TM4, to glycine resulted in the loss of one of the two Ca 2+ binding sites. The loss-offunction mutation supports these residues to be essential for Ca 2+ binding (Skerjanc et al., 1993) . Inside the membrane, FITC-binding (Lys 529 ) and FITC-reaction site (Lys 711 ) are present in T. squamosa. FITC is a strong inhibitor of SERCA, completely inhibiting Ca 2+ uptake activity (Pick and Bassilian, 1981) .
body_text.section: Molecular characteristics of SERCA-like from the ctenidium and inner mantle of Tridacna squamosa

body_text.text: SERCA-like of T. squamosa had high sequence similarity with SER-CA2a (73.16%) and SERCA1 (73.11%) of H. sapiens. Furthermore, there were also high similarities in the amino acid sequences between SERCAlike of T. squamosa and the three SERCA isoforms of the Akoya pearl oyster, Pinctada fucata (86.03% for PSERC, 85.23% for PSERA and 83.98% for PSERB). For P. fucata, SERCA isoforms are named with a different nomenclature: PSERA, PSERB and PSERC. Specifically, SERCAlike of T. squamosa shows the highest similarity (86.03%) with PSERC, which is expressed mainly in gills and the mantle of P. fucata (Fan et al., 2007) . Phenogramic analysis also denotes the grouping of SERCA-like of T. squamosa with SERCA from bivalves, including the freshwater pearl mussel, Hyriopsis cumingii, and the eastern oyster, Crassostrea virginica. Unlike SERCA2 of vertebrates, SERCA-like of T. squamosa lacks the characteristic phospholamban-binding motif KDDKPV (Lys 397 -Val 402 ).
body_text.section: Molecular characteristics of SERCA-like from the ctenidium and inner mantle of Tridacna squamosa

body_text.text: There is little information on the regulation of plant type Ca 2+ -ATPases that are homologous to vertebrate SERCA (Kabała and Kłobus, 2005) . In animals, SERCA can be regulated by multiple mechanisms like hormonal control (Kimura et al., 1994) , transcriptional control (Watanabe et al., 2011), post-translational modifications (Stammers et al., 2015) , redox balance (Kuster et al., 2010) and interactions with other proteins (Bhupathy et al., 2007; Periasamy et al., 2008) . In small mammals, thyroid hormones control the transcriptional activity of SERCA2 and regulate the expression of SERCA2 proteins (Nagai et al., 1989; Kimura et al., 1994) . SERCA can also be regulated by posttranslational modifications (Stammers et al., 2015) . In rat myocytes, redox-mediated regulation can inhibit SERCA activity by irreversibly oxidising cysteine thiols (Kuster et al., 2010) . In addition, binding of phospholamban or sarcolipin to SERCA decreases its affinity to Ca 2+ , resulting in lower SERCA2a activity (Periasamy et al., 2008) . As SERCAlike of T. squamosa lacks the phospholamban-binding motif KDDKPV, it may not be regulated by phospholamban. However, there is a scarcity of example of increased expression levels of SERCA in response to illumination in animals. Yet, exposure of T. squamosa to light for 6 or 12 h significantly increased the protein abundance of SERCA-like in the ctenidium and the inner mantle, although the transcript level of SERCA-like decreased in the ctenidium at hour 12 while remaining unchanged in the inner mantle. These results are novel and indicate that SERCA-like is regulated at the translational level in these two organs of T. squamosa in response to light. Translational regulation would circumvent energetic requirements of transcriptional regulation related to synthesis, processing and exporting of mRNA, and allow for a faster response to external changes (Lackner and Bähler, 2008) . Importantly, the increase in protein abundance of SERCA-like would augment the capacity of Ca 2+ sequestration into the ER in the cells of the ctenidial epithelium and the shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle in T. squamosa exposed to light.
body_text.section: Is light-enhanced SERCA-like expression in T. squamosa atypical?

body_text.text: Two separate studies have made attempts to elucidate whether the diel fluctuations in expression levels of manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD; Hiong et al., 2018) and Na + /Ca 2+ exchanger 3 (NCX3; Boo et al., 2019) in T. squamosa could be attributable to circadian rhythm. Individuals of T. squamosa were exposed to 12 h + 12 h (a total of 24 h) of darkness or 24 h of darkness followed by 12 h of light, as compared with individuals exposed to 12 h of darkness (control) or 12 h of darkness followed with 12 h of light. These studies concluded that changes in the expression levels of MnSOD in the outer mantle (Hiong et al., 2018) and NCX3-like (Boo et al., 2019) in the inner mantle of T. squamosa were unrelated to circadian rhythm, as they occur in response to light even after the giant clams had been exposed experimentally to darkness for 24 h. Hence, it is logical to deduce that the increases in protein abundance of SERCA-like in the ctenidium and the inner mantle of T. squamosa were probably resulted from a general light-responsive signaling mechanism that coordinate the gene and protein expression levels of a variety of transporters in multiple organs in relation to various diurnally light-dependent physiological processes.
body_text.section: Is light-enhanced SERCA-like expression in T. squamosa atypical?

body_text.text: Light-enhanced shell formation requires an increase in Ca 2+ absorption from the surrounding seawater. In T. squamosa, increased exogenous Ca 2+ uptake can occur in the ctenidium, which expresses CACNA1-like, the pore-forming subunit of VGCCs. CACNA1-like is localized in the apical membrane of epithelial cells of ctenidial filaments and tertiary water channels, which are structured to increase the surface area for membrane transport (Cao-Pham et al., 2019b) . After illumination, the protein abundance of CACNA1-like increases significantly in the ctenidium of T. squamosa, suggesting that it supports increased Ca 2+ uptake into the ctenidial epithelial cells (Cao-Pham et al., 2019b) . However, the resulting high intracellular Ca 2+ concentration would theoretically disrupt intracellular signaling pathways and precipitate phosphates (Clapham, 2007) . Our results obtained indicate that the absorbed Ca 2+ could traverse ctenidial epithelial cells through the ER, similar to milk secretion in mammary gland (Faddy et al., 2008) and mineralisation during ecdysis in arthropods (Hagedorn et al., 2003) , because of three reasons. Firstly, both transporters have similar cellular localization in the ctenidial filaments of T. squamosa. Secondly, at the subcellular level, CACNA1-like is apically localized in the membranes of the epithelial cells of the ctenidial filaments, while SERCA-like is localized non-uniformly in the cytoplasm of these cells, with apparent concentration in the apical region. Hence, Ca 2+ that has entered the cell through CACNA1-like can be taken up by SERCA-like into the ER. Thirdly, the protein abundance of SERCA-like and CACNA1-like significantly increased in the ctenidium after 12 h of light exposure, indicating a gradual increase in their protein abundance between hour 6 and hour 12. A priori, an increase in the protein abundance of SERCA-like in the ctenidium during light exposure, as substantiated by the immunofluorescence results, would increase the capacity of Ca 2+ transport into the ER, which aligns well with the increased Ca 2+ uptake through CACNA1like (Cao-Pham et al., 2019b) . Thus, low cytosolic Ca 2+ concentration in the ctenidial epithelial cells can be maintained, although how Ca 2+ moves across the ER lumen is uncertain at present. It has been proposed that intra-ER Ca 2+ movement can be guided by calsequestrin and calreticulin (Berridge et al., 2003) , but whether these proteins are involved in the ctenidial epithelial cells of T. squamosa needs further investigation.
body_text.section: Light-enhanced expression of SERCA-like in the ctenidial epithelium supports light-enhanced Ca 2+ uptake

body_text.text: In T. squamosa, Ca 2+ absorbed by the ctenidium must be translocated through the hemolymph to the inner mantle which participates in lightenhanced shell formation. In general, Ca 2+ is transported in plasma as dissolved ions or as a complex bound to proteins, such as albumin. Nonionic Ca 2+ transport has been described in the Eastern oyster, Crassostrea virginica, which possess in the hemolymph refractive granulocytes that contain CaCO 3 (Mount et al., 2004) . It has been reported that these CaCO 3 -containing granulocytes can release the CaCO 3 crystals at the mineralisation front of C. virginica (Mount et al., 2004) . However, how the granulocytes can cross the shell-facing epithelium, and get access to the extrapallial fluid where shell formation occurs has not been elucidated. At present, the route and mechanism of Ca 2+ translocation in the hemolymph of T. squamosa is uncertain.
body_text.section: SERCA-like of shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle supports increased supply of Ca 2+ from the hemolymph to the extrapallial fluid during illumination

body_text.text: During shell formation, CaCO 3 is deposited from the extrapallial fluid onto the inner surface of the shell valve, and the inner mantle is in direct contact with the extrapallial fluid. To increase CaCO 3 precipitation during light-enhanced shell formation, the host must augment Ca 2+ supply from the hemolymph through the shell-facing epithelial cells of the inner mantle to the extrapallial fluid during illumination. In T. squamosa, two apical transporters can be involved: PMCA (Ip et al., 2017) and NCX3-like (Boo et al., 2019) , and the expression levels of these two transporters in the inner mantle are upregulated by light. It would imply that the quantity of Ca 2+ traversing the shell-facing epithelial cells of the inner mantle would increase during illumination, and there must be mechanisms to avoid the disruption of intracellular Ca 2+ homeostasis. Our results show that, similar to the case of ctenidium, SERCA-like could be the mechanism involved. In the inner mantle of T. squamosa, SERCA-like was localized non-uniformly in the cytoplasm of the epithelial cells facing the extrapallial fluid, and the protein abundance of SERCA-like was up-regulated by illumination, corroborating with the results derived from immunofluorescence microscopy. Hence, it is probable that the low intracellular Ca 2+ concentration is maintained by transporting Ca 2+ into the ER during light-enhanced shell formation, but whether the intra-ER Ca 2+ movement is guided by calsequestrin and calreticulin (Berridge et al., 2003) is unclear at present.
body_text.section: SERCA-like of shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle supports increased supply of Ca 2+ from the hemolymph to the extrapallial fluid during illumination

body_text.text: Notably, in T. squamosa, the seawater-facing epithelial cells has much weaker SERCA-like immunolabeling than the shell-facing epithelial cells in the inner mantle, which can have two implications.
body_text.section: SERCA-like of shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle supports increased supply of Ca 2+ from the hemolymph to the extrapallial fluid during illumination

body_text.text: Firstly, SERCA-like should be expressed, albeit to different extent, in all cell types and has multiple functions in Ca 2+ metabolism. The differential immunolabeling of SERCA-like between these two epithelia of T. squamosa supports the proposition that it would play a role in the translocation of Ca 2+ across the shell-facing epithelium in support of light-enhanced shell formation. Secondly, the weak expression of SERCA-like in the seawater-facing epithelium of the inner mantle of T. squamosa corroborates the proposition that increased exogenous Ca 2+ uptake for light-enhanced shell-formation occurred mainly at the ctenidium, and not the inner mantle.
body_text.section: SERCA-like of shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle supports increased supply of Ca 2+ from the hemolymph to the extrapallial fluid during illumination

body_text.text: Scleractianian corals form skeletons by depositing aragonite crystals in the subcalicoblastic medium underlying the calicoblastic (calcifying) epithelium. Unlike giant clams, skeleton formation in scleractinian corals may involve the formation of intracellular CaCO 3 instead of the translocation of Ca 2+ across the calicoblastic cells, as amorphous CaCO 3 can be found inside coral cells (Mass et al., 2017) . Furthermore, PMCA (Barott et al., 2015) and NCX (Barron et al., 2018) are localized in the cytoplasm and intracellular vesicles, respectively, of calicoblastic cells of scleractinian coral, Acropora yongei. Calicoblastic cells also express HCO 3 − transporting proteins that could supply inorganic carbon (Zoccola et al., 2015; Barott et al., 2015; Tresguerres et al., 2017) and coral acidic rich proteins (CARPs) that can catalyze aragonite formation even at pH ~7.6 (Mass et al., 2013 (Mass et al., , 2014 (Mass et al., , 2017 . Intracellular amorphous CaCO 3 can be secreted together with HCO 3 − , CARPs, and several other proteins into the subcalicoblastic medium for skeleton formation (Von Euw et al., 2017) . Hence, it is logical to propose that scleractinian corals may not need to maintain a low intracellular [Ca 2+ ] in the calicoblastic cells through light-enhanced expression of SERCA during light-enhanced skeleton formation. Future studies are needed to confirm such a proposition.
body_text.section: SERCA-like of shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle supports increased supply of Ca 2+ from the hemolymph to the extrapallial fluid during illumination

body_text.text: Giant clams live in symbiosis with symbiotic dinoflagellates that can donate their photosynthates to support host's growth (Fisher et al., 1985; Hawkins and Klumpp, 1995) . This can partly explain why giant clams could afford energetically to have higher rates of shell formation in light than in darkness (Sano et al., 2012; Rossbach et al., 2019) . As a corollary, many of the host's physiological activities need to be aligned with the photosynthetic activity in the symbionts. Indeed, many host transporters partaking in these physiological processes display lightenhanced gene and protein expression. The ctenidium of T. squamosa possess transporters that take part in absorption of Ca 2+ (CACNA1-like, Cao-Pham et al., 2019b; SERCA-like, this study), inorganic carbon (Dual Domain Carbonic Anhydrase; Koh et al., 2018) , urea (DUR3-like; Chan et al., 2018), glucose (SGLT1; Chan et al., 2019) , nitrate (SIALIN-like; Ip et al., 2020) and phosphate (NPT2a-like; Chan et al., 2020) . It also possesses transporters for the excretion of excess H + (Na + /H + Exchanger 3-like; Hiong et al., 2017; VHA subunit A; Ip et al., 2018) . The inner mantle of T. squamosa possesses transporters that participate in the uptake of inorganic carbon (CA4-like; Chew et al., 2019) , the secretion of Ca 2+ (PMCA; Ip et al., 2017; NCX3-like; Boo et al., 2019 ; SERCA-like, this study), the excretion of H + (βNHE-like; Cao-Pham et al., 2019) and the maintenance of Na + and K + gradients (NKA; Boo et al., 2017) . The regulation of these transporters/enzymes at the transcriptional and translational levels is energy-intensive, but the host clam could afford it probably because of the constant supply of photosynthates from its symbionts. Taken together, it becomes apparent that the host clam has developed some kind of light-dependent regulatory mechanisms to control the gene and/or protein expression levels of these transporter and enzymes, and efforts should be made in the future to elucidate those regulatory mechanisms.
